item.description:
I‚Äôve been digging into some new music this month. And by new music, I mean there‚Äôs also a bunch of stuff from a few years ago, and some of that is incredibly generous with the word ‚Äúfew‚Äù.

Here‚Äôs what I‚Äôve been listening to.

Lonely Magic‚ÄîRebecca Sugar

Rebecca Sugar is the creator of Stephen Universe, and before that, a writer and storyboard artist for Adventure Time. They wrote a lot of the music on both shows, and now they‚Äôre doing albums unconnected with TV. And you know what? They‚Äôre great! I heard them on The Best Show and decided to check out their latest album, Lonely Magic. It is musically varied, and Rebecca‚Äôs voice has a lovely, intimate quality. Highly recommend if you like either shows music, or just lovely, solid songs.

Endless‚ÄîMagic Sword

I really like Magic Sword. 80s dance synth that takes you on a journey? What‚Äôs not to like. I own most of their releases digitally, but Endless slipped past me for some reason. It‚Äôs fun!

Stiff Upper Lip‚ÄîAC/DC

item.title: Dad Reviews Robert Redford's Career üçø
item.description:
My dad texted out of the blue, this time about Robert Redford.

In honor of Robert Redford‚Äôs passing, I‚Äôm watching Barefoot in the Park. Redford is paired with the one and only Jane Fonda. The movie is from 1967. Rose [my grandmother] took me to see it then at Radio City Music Hall. That was a thing. She took me every year for a few years. A Nice memory. BTW I don‚Äôt remember anything of the movie except the opening scene.

I hadn‚Äôt seen the movie, so I asked what the opening scene was.

A horse and carriage ride through Central Park. Jane and Robert had just gotten married. Yeah Kane did a great job with the wife character.

Great, I knew the opening scene in vivid detail, but nothing of the film overall. I could look up a synopsis, but I didn‚Äôt want to see the whole plot clinically laid out. Instead, I asked if there were any other memorable scenes.

Yeah after they find out they are incompatible she asks for a divorce six days into the marriage.

Perfect. I gotta go see Barefoot in the Park now.

item.title: localmart: why, what, and a visualization
item.description:
why & what</h2>

For the first couple months of the year, I was working on an idea called localmart</strong>.</p>

The motivation behind of localmart</strong> is this:</p>

  1. Lots of people today order things from Amazon that they could get in their neighborhood.</li>
  2. That means that money is being extracted from local neighborhoods into global corporations.</li>
  3. So what if we were able to provide the Amazon.com</a> experience, but all the goods are sourced from local stores so that your money gets reinvested into your neighborhood?</li> </ol>

    So in short, localmart</strong> is a service where you order local goods from local stores, and it gets delivered within a day or two.</p>

    visualization</h2>

    I've had a visualization in mind to explain localmart</strong> to folks, so here's a quick version.</p>

    Cash is flowing out to corporations, but with more local orders, cash stays in the neighborhood and makes the neighborhood healthier.</p>

item.title: Working with Electron
item.description:
Working with Electron</a> is a pleasure. I just built an app called Redub</a> with it. For the uninitiated, here is how the creators describe Electron:</p>

Electron is a framework for creating native applications with web technologies like JavaScript, HTML, and CSS.</p> </blockquote>

Most programmers know how to build web apps. Now, with that same knowledge, you can build cross-platform desktop apps.</p>

Electron gets a lot</a> of</a> crap</a> for being too resource intensive and for enabling lazy developers. The haters say that better frameworks for desktop apps already exist and that you should use those instead.</p>

They're right, Electron apps are more intensive than I'd like. For those unaware, it's because every app has a full browser baked into it. That's how you're able to use Javascript, HTML, and CSS.</p>

But let me be the first to say: the haters are missing the point, as usual. The real value of Electron is that it lets you move from random idea</strong> to cross-platform app</strong> fast, using the web dev knowledge you probably already have (which also means you have a huge community to draw from).</p>

item.title: Insert an audio clip to a video file with FFMPEG
item.description:
The goal</h3>

For a hobby project of mine</a>, I wanted to be able to merge an audio clip into the existing audio track of a video file.</p>

The command</h3>

After struggling for an hour or two, I finally came up with the correct incantation of the command ffmpeg</code> to overlay an audio clip to a video file:</p> 

ffmpeg \ -i movie.mkv \ -i new-audio-clip.mp3 \ -filter_complex "[1:0] adelay=2728000|2728000 [delayed];[0:1][delayed] amix=inputs=2" \ -map 0:0 \ -c:a aac -strict -2 \ -c:v copy \ output.mp4 </code></pre> 
The explanation</h3> 
Line by line:</p> 
     
  • -i movie.mkv</strong>: set the video/audio file as an input</li> 
  • -i new-audio-clip.mp3</strong>: set the audio clip as an input</li> 
  • -filter_complex "..."</strong>: specify the two following filters: 
       
    • "[1:0] adelay=2728000|2728000 [delayed]</strong>: the adelay filter, specifically: 
         
      • [1:0]</strong>: using the second input file's first stream</li> 
      • adelay=2728000|2728000</strong>: add a delay of 2,728,000 milliseconds to both channels of the audio (the left and right channels, because the audio is stereo)</li> 
      • [delayed]</strong>: assign the name "delayed" to the new stream</li> </ul> </li> 
      • [0:1][delayed] amix=inputs=2</strong>: the amix filter, specifically: 
           
        • [0:1][delayed]</strong>: using the first input's second stream and the "delayed" stream</li> 
        • amix=inputs=2</strong>: mix the two audio streams (NOTE: I'm not 100% on the meaning of inputs=2</strong> here)</li> </ul> <

item.title: A React Native library to run commands over SSH
item.description:
For my React Native app Hooks</a>, I wrote some native Android code to enable the running of arbitrary commands over SSH.</p>

I've now added the iOS side, and after some refactoring, the SSH code for both platforms is now its own library: react-native-ssh</a>.</p>

There are no tests and it's very light on the error handling. But I figured I'd put it out there for others to use and/or improve upon.</p>

Native dependency pains</h2>

Gradle (the Android build system) lets you specify dependencies from Maven (Java's package repository). This meant that including the Android SSH library I needed was a single line. Nice and easy.</p>

Installing third-party dependencies on the iOS side of things is a pain, though. First, a disclaimer: I'm by no means an iOS developer, and have only dealt with XCode and CocoaPods a handful of times.</p>

I first tried to make my library a pod to be installed via CocoaPods, which would allow it to have its own dependencies. However, there are two problems with installing a React Native library as a pod:</p>

  • it has to list React as one of its dependencies, which is deprecated</li>
  • it's incompatible with react-native link</strong> which links your iOS library for you, and would result in duplicate libraries in XCode</li> </ul>

item.title: A mobile app to run scripts on servers
item.description:
Over the years, whether I was working with a Raspberry Pi or running a server, there would often be one-off scripts that I would want to run. The usual pattern would be:</p>

  • SSH into the server</li>
  • Run a single command</li>
  • Logout</li> </ul>

    I always thought it would be nice to have a phone app that could easily run those scripts.</p>

    I'd try some mobile SSH client but those felt clunky; a full-blown terminal was overkill. I just wanted to quickly run a single script.</p>

    Other times I'd write a quick Flask app to listen on obscure ports and URLs to trigger a script. This also felt like overkill, though, because I really didn't want to have to expose some HTTP server on some port just to run a script on occasion.</p>

    So I decided to bite the bullet and write the app that I wanted.</p>

    Hooks</h2>

    The app is simple. It works as follows:</p>

    • Add a server's SSH credentials</li>
    • You'll see a list of the executable files in ~/.hooks-app/hooks</strong></li>
    • Tap one of them and it will run</li> </ul>

      I myself have started to use this for a few things, including making sure all the containers are running properly on this server.</p>

      </p>

      What I learned</h2>

      This was the first time I used React and it's libraries. I have to say that using it, particularly together with Redux, felt elegant and safe. The fact that a global state defines the UI really makes things simpler.</p>

item.title: A simple image to backup volumes to S3
item.description:
One part of setting up my online presence naturally includes getting backups going.</p>

Since I'm trying to keep everything containerized, I did some research into what Amazon S3 backup solutions are out there. I found a popular project called dockup</a> that basically does everything I wanted to have done.</p>

However, upon looking at what I had to configure, I thought it could be simpler.</p>

How dockup works</h2>

In order to get dockup</strong> working, you have to mount the volumes you want to backup to some arbitrary place in the filesystem, and provide the following environment variables:</p>

  • AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID</li>
  • AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY</li>
  • AWS_DEFAULT_REGION</li>
  • BACKUP_NAME</li>
  • PATHS_TO_BACKUP</li>
  • S3_BUCKET_NAME</li> </ul>

    So, in English, given a bunch of directories (specified in PATHS_TO_BACKUP), dockup</strong> will create a timestamped backup (using the name BACKUP_NAME) in the bucket S3_BUCKET_NAME.</p>

    I'd do it a bit differently</h2>

    My ideal backup image would work different in a few ways.</p>

    First, I want a separate backup for each of my apps. At any given time, I'm not sure which services I will be running. Maybe I'll stop the blog and keep the git repo running. Or maybe I'll add a new service. I want to keep the data for each of those services separate.</p>

    Next, I shouldn't have to specify which directories I want to backup. I could just put my volumes somewhere specific, like /backups</strong>.</p>

    Finally, the structure of the backup directory can contain the bucket and name. For example, any data in the directory /backups/app-backups/blog-data</strong> will be bundled

item.title: Anatomy of this site's Docker Compose file
item.description:
As it stands, this server has two services running: a blog and git repository. They're both routed to by an nginx proxy, and my free SSL certificates are provided by the oh-so-wonderful Let's Encrypt.</p>

The best part is that all of that is defined in and deployed by using a single Docker Compose file.</p>

That means the only thing I had to do on my server was install Docker</a> (which is made easy by Docker Machine</a>). The rest happens inside containers that play well with each other thanks to Docker Compose</a>.</p>

I'm going to explain the file section by section, but first, here's all of it:</p> 

version: '2' services: nginx-proxy: image: jwilder/nginx-proxy:0.4.0 container_name: nginx-proxy ports: - "80:80" - "443:443" volumes: - certs:/etc/nginx/certs:ro - /etc/nginx/conf.d - /etc/nginx/vhost.d - /usr/share/nginx/html - /var/run/docker.sock:/tmp/docker.sock:ro environment: - DEFAULT_HOST=ptrvldz.me letsencrypt-nginx-proxy: image: jrcs/letsencrypt-nginx-proxy-companion container_name: letsencrypt-nginx-proxy volumes_from: - nginx-proxy volumes: - /var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock:ro - certs:/etc/nginx/certs:rw blog: image: ghost:0.11.2 container_name: blog volumes: - ghost:/var/lib/ghost environment: - VIRTUAL_HOST=ptrvldz.me - LETSENCRYPT_HOST=ptrvldz.me - LETSENCRYPT_EMAIL=webmaster@ptrvldz.me git: image: gogs/gogs:0.9.97 container_name: git volumes: -

item.title: Back online
item.description:
It's been a while since I've had any form of personal site.</p>

Every time I wanted to start one, I would overthink it.</p>

I'd think about the various apps I wanted to host, like a blog, a git repository, a file server, maybe even my own mail. And it'd be all nicely organized and deployable.</p>

But in the end, all I'd do was think and not do.</p>

So today, simple beginnings:</p>

  • A blog at ptrvldz.me</a></li>
